abstract.p: R T Davies letter on Marilyn Stasio's May 28 travel essay on Moscow questions whether Polish soldiers are being sent from Gdasnk on leave to Moscow; Stasio responds (S)

block.p: To the Editor: In her essay about Moscow and its lost great spies, ''Lament for Karla'' (May 28), Marilyn Stasio writes about the ''little army of fuzz-faced soldiers who marched up to me'' and ''only wanted to have their pictures taken to send home to their mothers in Gdansk.''

As one who spent many years in both the Soviet Union and Poland, I was surprised to read this. Are the Poles, now that they belong to NATO, sending their conscripts from Gdansk on leave to Moscow? Or were some Russian recruits playing a strange sort of game, claiming their mothers were in that faraway city on the Baltic coast?

To the Editor: In her essay about Moscow and its lost great spies, ''Lament for Karla'' (May 28), Marilyn Stasio writes about the ''little army of fuzz-faced soldiers who marched up to me'' and ''only wanted to have their pictures taken to send home to their mothers in Gdansk.''

As one who spent many years in both the Soviet Union and Poland, I was surprised to read this. Are the Poles, now that they belong to NATO, sending their conscripts from Gdansk on leave to Moscow? Or were some Russian recruits playing a strange sort of game, claiming their mothers were in that faraway city on the Baltic coast?

It was nice to read that Ms. Stasio had tea in the good old Metropol, where my wife and I lived for many months in 1952. We had a board we put across the bathtub, on top of which we placed our two-burner electric stove, which worked fine most of the time and blew the fuses the rest of it.

Ms. Stasio responds: Like all my impromptu conversations in Moscow, this effort to communicate with young soldiers was a source of some hilarity to the group -- no doubt because of my total ignorance of their language. But one linguist among them had enough English to determine that I was from New York, and when he pointed to his friends and began reeling off place names, I assumed I was being given their hometowns. It's possible, though, that I was mishearing their given names. Or perhaps getting the latest soccer scores.
